links.title: TempleOS Archive
links.description: An operating system built by Terry A. Davis in HolyC. Designed to be a modern Commodore-64 and a divine temple.

links.title: KolibriOS
links.description: Tiny, fast OS written in assembly. Boots in seconds, fits on a floppy disk, and includes a GUI, text editor, and more.

links.title: Haiku OS
links.description: Open-source continuation of BeOS—designed for speed, efficiency, and simplicity with a native GUI.

links.title: Serenity OS
links.description: A beautiful UNIX-like OS built from scratch. Clean C++ codebase, custom GUI, and growing developer following.

links.title: ReactOS
links.description: Windows-compatible open-source OS aimed at binary-level compatibility with Windows apps and drivers.

links.title: Plan 9 from Bell Labs
links.description: Experimental OS from Bell Labs focused on distributed computing and a unified file interface. Very influential in systems design.

tips.title: Try in a VM First
tips.content: Many alternative OSes aren’t suited for real hardware. Use VirtualBox, QEMU, or GNOME Boxes to test them safely.

tips.title: Expect the Unexpected
tips.content: Most alt OSes don’t follow Linux conventions—don’t expect systemd, apt, or bash. Embrace the weird.

tips.title: Join Small Communities
tips.content: Alt OS communities are often small but passionate. Forums, IRC, and GitHub issues are great ways to get help.

tips.title: Look at the Source Code
tips.content: Many of these OSes are written from scratch. Browsing their code is a masterclass in kernel design and UI architecture.

tips.title: Host ISOs for the Future
tips.content: Preserve early versions of rare or discontinued OSes. You may be the last mirror one day.

tips.title: Use Read-Only Images
tips.content: Some of these OSes can corrupt disks or write in odd formats. Use ISO boot mode or snapshots to avoid issues.
